title: Westpac shares climb after capital raising, rate increase
text:
Westpac chief executive Brian Hartzer Westpac is seeking to pass on the bank's cost of holding more capital to customers, as well as investors.
A strong surge in Westpac's share price could give other banks further encouragement to follow its lead and lift their mortgage rates.
Shares in the country's second-largest bank jumped to $31.34 on Monday, 3 per cent higher than their closing pricing from last Tuesday, before trading in the stock was halted for a $3.5 billion capital raising.
They've kind of gotten away with it, so the other banks will probably be thinking, 'will we do the same thing'?
Watermark Funds Management investment analyst Omkar Joshi Andrew Martin, principal at fund manager Alphinity, said "a reasonable amount" of Monday's share price rise probably reflected Westpac's decision to raise mortgage rates 0.2 percentage points at the same time as it raised capital.
Since Westpac's move, Mr Martin said the market was "more certain" that the cost of tougher capital rules would be shared between customers and investors.
Advertisement "The pendulum has shifted a bit from shareholders copping all the dilution to actually, some of this can be borne by the customers as well, and therefore shareholders don't have to cop all the cost of the capital requirements," said Mr Martin, who is invested in Westpac.
John Abernethy, founder of Clime Investment Management, said the rally in Westpac's share price was only partly driven by its decision to raise mortgage rates – he believes a bigger factor was probably covering of short positions that had built up in anticipation of a capital raising.
"The other banks will probably follow suit. It is an oligopoly, so why would they be charging less for loans when they could be charging more?" Mr Abernethy said.
While Westpac shares were also catching up to several days of rises in other bank stocks, it has been the strongest-performing bank share since last Tuesday's close, even though it has diluted investors with an equity raising during this period.
Since last Tuesday's close, Commonwealth Bank shares have gained 2.9 per cent, National Australia Bank shares are up 2.3 per cent, and ANZ Bank shares have risen 1.2 per cent.
Watermark Funds Management investment analyst Omkar Joshi said the positive reaction might encourage other banks to follow suit but they would be wary of political reaction.
"They've kind of gotten away with it, so the other banks will probably be thinking, 'will we do the same thing'? But the question is by how much, and I don't think they will increase their rates 0.2 percentage points," Mr Joshi said.
David Ellis, head of banking research at Morningstar, said Westpac's share price may also have risen due to stronger-than-expected performance in its profit margins.
"I think it's a sensible response from Westpac and I expect to see the other banks follow," Mr Ellis said.
"The cost of a much so-called 'safer' banking system is borne not just by shareholders, it is going to be borne by customers as well."
Westpac's raising, via an entitlement offer, allows shareholders to buy one new share for every 23 held at $25.50 a share, a discount of 13.6 per cent to the dividend-adjusted pre-raising price of $29.50.
A letter from chairman Lindsay Maxsted sent to retail shareholders on Monday highlighted that the bank was still lifting dividends, with a final dividend rising 2¢ compared with a year ago, to 94¢ a share.
"We also recognise the importance of dividends to shareholders and while we are raising capital and increasing the number of shares on issue, we have not changed our dividend approach," Mr Maxsted said.
